name: Core Quiz 1: Software Engineering Concepts Quiz
description: In this quiz, we will review a few Software Engineering Concepts. The quiz can be taken for one time only. There is no time limit. (It normally takes 20 - 30 mins to complete the quiz.). Remember for question 7, you will be required to do some research on Entity-Relationship models.

name: Core Quiz 2: Processes, Requirements, UI Design, Class Diagram
description:
Instructions:

In this quiz, we will review a few important concepts we learned from Week 03 - Week 05. The quiz can be taken twice. The last submission will be graded. There is no time limit. (It normally takes 30-50 mins to complete the quiz.)

A recommended process:

1. Take the quiz for the first time, without using any reference materials. See how much you have learned, and what your muddy points are (if any).

2. Read the reference materials, including slides, book chapters, library e-books, etc.

3. Take the quiz for the second time.

Notes:

  • As usual, the last question is used to ask for your feedback with the class. You can answer this question in the last attempt only.
  • The quizzes are designed to help you review the materials we have covered so far. Please try to get most out of these quizzes/assignments by thinking through the questions.

name: One Picture, One Paragraph
description:
Please upload a picture of yourself and write a paragraph to introduce yourself to the instructor. Your information will be kept confidential, and will only be used to help the instructor get to know you better.

Please include your software engineering related strengths, any weaknesses you would like to share and your short term and long term goals.

name: CodingBat-1 (AP-1)
description:
This is an individual assignment. No collaboration is allowed on this assignment! :)

In this assignment, you will try to solve as many CodingBat problems as you can. The detailed instructions is as follows:

1. Visit https://codingbat.com/ (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site., sign up an account if you don't have one.

2. Go to "prefs" at the upper right corner, type the instructor's email (Jagannadha.Chidella@csus.edu) in the field next to "Share to" at "Teacher Share" section. (If you don't share your progress with me, I cannot give you credits based on the work you have completed.)

3. On the same page, type your Sac State email + "Section #, SPRING23" in the "Memo" field. For example, "genos@csus.edu, Section 1, SPRING23". 

4. Go to Java coding page: https://codingbat.com/java (Links to an external site.)Links to an external site., and try to solve as many AP-1 problems as you can. 

Your grade will be given based on the number of problems you completely solved with 100% test cases passed. To get full credits (50 pts), at least 3 AP-1, 1 Functional-1 and 1 Functional-2 problems should be solved. Of course, please feel free to try other types of problems, such as String, Array, Logic, etc.

There is nothing to submit on Canvas. However, please enter a text submission on canvas on how to find you on CodingBat such as your email address.

name: CodingBat - 2 (String-3)
description:
This is an individual assignment. No collaboration is allowed on this assignment! :)

In this assignment, you will continue to work on CodingBat. The detailed instructions is as follows:

This exercise will be useful to process strings for the Project.

1. Visit https://codingbat.com/, sign up an account if you don't have one.

2. Go to "prefs" at the upper right corner, type the instructor's email (jagannadha.chidella@csus.edu) in the field next to "Share to" at "Teacher Share" section. (If you don't share your progress with me, I cannot give you credits based on the work you have completed.)

3. On the same page, type your Sac State email "Section #, SPRING23" in the "Memo" field. For example, "genos@csus.edu, Section 1, SPRING23". 

4. Go to Java coding page: https://codingbat.com/java, and try to solve as many String-3 problems as you can. 

There is nothing to submit on Canvas. However, please enter a text submission on canvas on how to find you on CodingBat such as your email address.

Your grade will be given based on the number of problems you completely solved with 100% test cases passed. To get full credits (50 pts), at least 5 String-3 problems should be solved.

Tips for success:

  • Start early.
  • Try to solve one problem per day. Make it an incremental development :-)

name: HW01-A Activity Diagram (fork/join)
description:
Dear students,

This is an individual assignment.

However, you have the option to collaborate with others - In case you use this option, write everyone's names on top page and make sure only one student submits the assignment.  Please make sure all students collaborating have a thorough understanding of what you are submitting.

Please note the updated instructions:

You may start doing this assignment after we learn the fork/join principle in Activity diagrams.

This is an individual assignment. However, you may work with others - write everyone's names on top page and make sure only one student submits.   Submit one document with the diagram. Download Microsoft Visio (or Lucid Chart or Draw.io, most students like Draw.io). Using Visio or equivalent for the assignment will help you be professional. My personal recommendation is to start using Lucid Chart as most organizations have switched over to Lucid Chart.

If you were unable to download yet, please do so ASAP. Please export your diagram in PDF and submit.  If you are still unable to download Visio or equivalent tool by the due date, you may submit a camera picture of your diagram very neatly (dark and legible) done on paper. However, all future assignments will require Visio or equivalent UML drawing tool. You may use a lab to access Visio if you own a Mac or a non-Windows OS.

Problem description:

(You may use any of the following: Decision, Merge, Fork, Join, Action, Object and any other nodes. The more the better. :)

(i) You have green, red and blue marbles in a single box. The marbles are sorted in the following way by color. One marble is picked at a time from this box, the color of the marble is checked and placed in a green box if it is green, blue box if it is blue and red box if it is red. This process continues until all marbles have been placed in the respective boxes. The marbles are picked in sequence one after another. 

 ***After this step, the marbles in each box are counted and each box is labeled with the color and count.  This task is done in parallel for each of the boxes. ****

The three boxes are then placed in the garage. Assume placing the sorted boxes in the garage is a single task. (Note, the counting is NOT done while sorting the colors).

(ii) Modify the counting to happen while picking each color marble from the single box and provide a different version of the original diagram as well.

(iii) What do you propose to do if three people can pick one marble each simultaneously from the initial single box? Only provide an answer to this problem. No diagram is required.

cheers,

Jagan

name: HW01-B Activity Diagram (Find Max)
description:
This is an individual assignment.

However, you have the option to collaborate with others - If you use this option, you must write everyone's names on top page and make sure only one student submits.  Please make sure all students collaborating have a thorough understanding of what you are submitting.

Task:

Draw an activity diagram describing an algorithm for finding the top two maximum values in a list. The input is the list, and output is the top two maximum values.

Hints:

  • Make your own assumptions
  • Design/choose the algorithm first, then model it with an activity diagram
  • Include appropriate level of detail in your model

How to draw your model:

Option 1: You may draw your model on paper, take a picture of it.

Option 2:  Use instructions provided in Announcement to use Visio, or Lucid Chart of Draw.io

Deliverable:

In a PDF file, include the algorithm (in pseudocode) you chose, the assumptions you made, and your model. Submit the PDF file in Canvas.

name: HW 02 Modeling Software Processes in LUCID CHART (USE VISIO OR DRAW.IO ONLY IF YOU PREFER)
description:
This is an individual assignment.

However, you have the option of collaborating with others. If you use this option: Please write all your names on top of your PDF submission. (Both first and last names included) and only one student submits. Please make sure all students collaborating have a thorough understanding of what you are submitting.

(PLEASE START USING LUCID CHART.  ONLY IF YOU PREFER YOU MAY USE VISIO OR DRAW.IO)

'

Deliverable:

Refer to Week03 reading materials and slides, and use LUCID CHART (or Visio or Draw.io) to create a model (activity diagram) for the Waterfall, Prototype Evolution, Spiral, Generic Agile, and SCRUM process respectively. Add all five models into a PDF file and submit it through Canvas.

Note: You may create exactly the same models as it is shown in the reading materials, or you may try to create those models based on your own understanding. The key is to meet all of the objectives of this assignment.

name: HW03- Class and Sequence Diagram
description:
This is an individual assignment.

However, you have the option to collaborate with others - If you use this option, you must write everyone's names on top page and make sure only one student submits.  Please make sure all students collaborating have a thorough understanding of what you are submitting.

Watch the video on UML Class and Sequence diagrams (from the slides folder) to understand UML Class and Sequence Diagrams. The video is very comprehensive.

1. Instructions: HW03- Class Diagrams.docx

Deliverable: Please create a zip file with all your source code packages in it and submit it through Canvas.

 

2. Draw Sequence Diagrams for Activity Diagram homework assignments that you had completed. 

I want to clarify that just two sequence diagrams are sufficient: one for the fork/join activity diagram problem and another for the finding max activity diagram problem.  You are required to draw only for finding the first max (second max is not required) for the finding max activity.

Keep the sequence diagrams simple capturing the high-level abstraction and only relevant detail, since the purpose of sequence diagrams is to show the sequence of interactions.

You may use Draw.io, Lucid Chart or Visio for drawing the diagrams.

best wishes,

Jagan

name: Post-Midterm Survey
description: This is an anonymous survey for you to give feedback to my class. Please reflect on your learning experience within the first 8 weeks of this class, and give specific suggestions for improvement for both the instructor and yourself. Thanks!

name: In-Class Activity 01 on Introduction (Overview) Chapter
description:
Dear students, 

This is an individual assignment. However you may work with others - write everyone's names on top page and make sure only one student submits.  

Please read the introduction chapter Introduction.pdf  in Module-1 and answer the following questions in one, two or three sentences (please do not exceed three sentences if possible).  The introduction chapter introduces the concept of software engineering and provides a broad overview.  Hence it is critical that every student reads this chapter.

Please write (type) your answers and submit a PDF file. Please DO NOT submit until  your teams (groups) are created on Canvas.  

You can work with others, so please work in your group or team and make sure all  members are active participants and are contributing. Please submit only one copy for the group.  On the top of your paper clearly list all member names including first, last name and Student ID. 

1.  Explain the difference between Bespoke and Generic Software with your own examples.

2. Explain "Software" and explain "Engineering" and combine the two  to define "Software Engineering".

3. List the two areas of concern in Software Engineering.  Pick two concerns in each area (total four concerns) and describe in your own words the concerns of your choice.

4. There are several questions that you will ask before developing a software product in your company. Please choose any two questions and answer in your own words how would you answer the questions if you were given the responsibility.

5. Name two issues you may face while developing large products and answer how you will address these large scale product or project issues.

6.  In the Project Management Iron Triangle, explain what it means to have Quality at the center of the triangle.

7. Google and research the Scrum Alliance and Agile Alliance and choose one agile value out of the four Agile values and one agile principle out of the twelve agile principles and explain how you would creatively follow the two choices at your company in your own words.

Best wishes, :) :)

Jagan

name: Lab-FOUNDN-02-Github
description:
Dear students,

 

This is a team project. Feel free to collaborate on this lab with your project team. Only one  submission is required for your group.  Hence only one student need submit under your name. DO NOT FORGET TO WRITE ALL TEAM MEMBER NAMES (FIRST AND LAST NAME) ON TOP OF THE SUBMISSION.

Go to URL: https://github.com/, register an account with your SacState email, and then login.

Part 1)  Getting ready: Watch the following video tutorials if this is your first time to use Git with Eclipse.

A. How To Add Eclipse Project To GitHub | How to Commit, Push, Pull from Eclipse to GitHub

Link

B. Committing, pushing, pulling and resolving conflicts with git and Eclipse

Link

 

Part 2)  Working as a team:

1. Select one team member as the Git master of your group. The master needs to create a repository, and add your teammates and the instructor (jagannadha.chidella@csus.edu) as "Collaborators" in the "Settings" tab. (All members excluding the master will receive an email from Git, which informs you that you have been added to the master's repository.) 

2. All members clone the repository created by the master in your Eclipse.

3. All members create a java project named "Lab02" in your Eclipse, and link it to your local git repository. 

4. The master downloads Hello.java, add it to your Lab02 project in Eclipse. Update line 8 with his/her information, then save, commit, push the change to Git.

5. Everyone else (excluding the master) pull the latest change from Git, which is the java file just added by the master.

6. Everyone else tries to update line 9 in Hello.java with their own information. Save and commit to their local repository.

7. Everyone else try to push the index (your updates in your local repository) to Git, resolve conflicts if needed. To resolve a conflict, you will need to keep the information added by your teammates, by adding your line 9 as a new line underneath the latest line added by your teammates to Hello.java. (Do NOT erase other teammates' lines when resolving a conflict.)

8. When everyone finishes, the master checks Git repository, and sees whether Hello.java includes all team member's information in it. If not, ask your teammate(s) to push their changes.

[comment added:  Also, please add your github public link in a document or comment box in your submission so that it is accessible for grading.

Also any proof of collaboration of team members can be added to the submission].

********

                      however,  if any individual with confidence in yourself is facing extraordinary circumstances

**********

 

 

Thanks,

Jagan

Best wishes and cheers,

Jagan

rubric_settings.title: Rubric for Project Concept with User Stories and UML Diagrams

rubric.description: Use Correct Template For User Stories (there are only two standard templates). The "As a <user role> I want to <action> so that I can <outcome>" template is popular.
Go through the three C's (Card, Conversation and Confirmation) before finalizing user stories.
Please create all the PRODUCT BACKLOG ITEMS (PBI) for your project that you can detail at the start of the project. Include User Stories for your PBI.
Prioritize each user story and group user stories to be implemented in each sprint.
Estimate the tasks and provide a Risk number (1 is low risk 5 is high risk) and a Value number (1 is low value to the customer and stakeholders and 5 is high value to the customer and stakeholders).
Then for each user story write detailed requirements or tasks needed to accomplish the user stories in software (these are the traditional requirements). Enter these tasks in JIRA.
Name all the class objects you will need for your software implementation of your project.
Now draw Use Case Diagram, Class Diagram and Sequence Diagram.
Outline three risks under the three P's (People, Process and Product) perspective in a matrix for both predictable and unpredictable categories for each of the three P's.

name: Team Project Deliverable1: Concept, User Stories and Requirements
description:
Dear students,

This is a team assignment.

As you have completed your Scrum reading, I encourage you to go through the User Stories PPT under slides folder. 

This PPT was prepared with a lot of effort by a team of graduate students in the Project Management course and was shared by them for our class. It is a wonderful creation, all gleaned from a "bible" text book on user stories given below. 

OPTIONAL TEXT: User Stories Applied – For Agile Software Development, Mike Cohen

August 2015, Addison Wesley (Text optional) (PowerPoint Slides available on CANVAS)

http://athena.ecs.csus.edu/~buckley/CSc191/User-Stories-Applied-Mike-Cohn.pdf

 

This team assignment will be your team project kick-off (or team project initiation task).

Go through instructions in model project folder for your project: under Files --------->> Scrum_Project_Guidelines. Your team project is unique to you, and is decided by you as a team. You may follow the same methods provided in this folder. Use anything that makes sense and is useful from this folder to go as detailed as you can. Some of the items in the folder are mere examples from another project. So do not be confused. They are meant as pointers for your new project.

Get a head-start for your class team project by entering your user stories on JIRA or Vivify Scrum or Flying Donut,  by depending on the user stories slides (powerpoint) on writing user stories. Preferably please use JIRA. Since instructions are available only for JIRA and VivifyScrum. One team member creates the project and everyone participates creating and entering the user stories as part of your initial Product Backlog for your team project. Entering User stories is a team activity, however I encourage each team member to arrive at and finalize one user story. Feel free to break up a user story into smaller user stories as needed.  Make sure your user stories follow the INVEST and MOSCOW principles as detailed in the User Stories PPT under the slides folder.

TASKS:

 

1. Then write down each user story (these are considered modern agile requirements). Use the correct template for user stories as provided in the User Stories PPT and provide MOSCOW or INVEST principle attribute.

2. Please create all the PRODUCT BACKLOG ITEMS (PBI) for your project that you can detail at the start of the project. Include User Stories for your PBI. Go through the three C's (Card, Conversation and Confirmation) before this process. 

I prefer that you use JIRA Tool and enter the user stories in JIRA (in comparison with Vivify or Flying Donut). Tutorial for using JIRA is in the same  project guidelines folder under sub-folder: tools.

3. Prioritize each user story and group user stories to be implemented in each sprint. You do not need more than two sprints. But if you do have more than two sprints it is very good. Estimate the tasks and provide a Risk number (1 is low risk 5 is high risk) and a Value number (1 is low value to the customer and stakeholders and 5 is high value to the customer and stakeholders).

4.Then for each user story write detailed requirements or tasks needed to accomplish the user stories in software (these are the traditional requirements). Enter these tasks in JIRA.

5. Name all the class objects you will need for your software implementation of your project.

6. Now draw Use Case Diagram, Class Diagram and Sequence Diagram.

7. Outline any three RISKS, you can think of, under three categories: called the three P's (People, Process and Product) in a matrix for both predictable and unpredictable sub-categories. 

 Risk type        | People | Process | Product

---------------------------------------------------

Predictable      |               |               |

---------------------------------------------------

Unpredictable  |              |                |

 

8. Create an Interaction Design Document Section with your own application of interaction design principles.

Submit one single PDF document with all these items (and screen shots of JIRA screens OR a link to JIRA project for grading).

 

enjoy,

:)

Jagan

name: Creating PB
description:
In this in-class activity, your team will follow the instructions (Item 1) and set up your product backlog on VivifyScrum or JIRA (preferably JIRA since JIRA is becoming a standard). JIRA and VivifyScrum instructions are available in the Files folder:

The product backlog (Item 2) was created based on the original software requirements specification, and only GUI related requirements has been selected. Items 3 and 4 are given as reference documents. 

File items you may need:

  2. Product Backlog: ProductBacklog.docx

A completely set-up product backlog (meaning you have completed all 5 steps in the instructions).

Best wishes,

rubric.description: Use of High Cohesion and Low Coupling

name: Project Presentation
description:
Dear students,

The presentations are only to increase your self-confidence. 

Please stay within the time limit. Only highlight key features.

Please Note: you are not required to cover everything in the Rubric for your presentation.

Please submit your team presentations here after your presentations.

Please do your best to submit your PowerPoint and recorded video here before your presentation. If you prefer to make any changes later, you can resubmit again after your presentation. I will leave this available for submission until after your presentation. Make sure everyone in the team presents and uses equal amount of speaking time (no one speaks disproportionately more than any another member!). You have from 15 to 30 minutes total presentation time.

15 or less minutes is ideal so that all teams will be able to present within the two hours for each section! 

 

Best wishes and cheers,

Jagan

name: Team Project Final Deliverable2: UML, Design Patterns, Scrum, Risk Management
description:
Dear students,

I am publishing the project deliverable assignment in advance to give a head start to those who are ready to get started now building your code without UML designs or design patterns or scrum principles and build only enough Java classes. You can apply software engineering principles by adjusting your code as you go.  Teams please make sure you check your progress with me, especially when you are not sure, to make sure you understand your deliverable, and that you are moving in the right direction.

If you wish to use other languages other than Java:

For those who wish to deviate from Java and use another language, please make sure:

 (a) the language you use is object-oriented,

 (b) you are able to perform unit testing and coverage testing like JUnit and EclEmma and you are able to complete a similar lab on your own, while  mocking the lab that students programming in Java will do, using JUnit and EclEmma.

Scrum Management:

It is okay if you get started without Scrum. You will have a separate Scrum readings summary assignment. However once your Scrum reading summaries are submitted, you can formally begin using a scrum process model and  become agile. :)

Complexity:

Remember there is no requirement that your project should solve a complex problem or you should demonstrate extraordinary programming skills. You will not be evaluated on Programming or on complexity of problem solved. Please keep the problem you are solving very simple. You will be evaluated on use of Software Engineering principles and tools ONLY.

Option to build software on top of existing lab:

Please note that you can build your software on top of any existing lab.  The existing design patterns in the labs cannot be claimed. So you have to build two simple design patterns of your own applied to your application. Which means, you may use the logic of the ideas of the design patterns in slides and the code in the zip file examples provided to you. However you are required to tailor them to be usable in your application.

GRADING RUBRIC:

Your Project will be evaluated based on the following rubric:

1. Project Management/Scrum.  All Scrum meetings and Scrum process recorded in a PDF document. Sprints can be any number:

1(a) Assignment of Scrum Master and Product Owner (rotate roles among team members) (5 points)

1(b) Sprint planning meeting (5 points)

1(c) Sprint Review (5 points)

1(d) Sprint Retrospective (5 points)

(Total 20 points)

2. Handling User Stories (minimum 5 user stories) and use of unambiguous requirements in Scrum tool: 

Use of any Scrum tool such as Vivify, Flying Donut or Atlassian/JIRA with:

2(a) two examples of  CCC (Card, Conversation and Confirmation) in PDF document: (2*2 = 4 points)

2(b) story points, prioritization and task assignment using tool (2*3 = 6 points)

2(c) risk table on People, Process and Product - provide examples of minimum two risks for each of People, Process and Product pertaining to the problem and your risk management solution in same or separate PDF document or if possible in tool (2*3 = 6 points)

2(d) and burndown chart (4 points)

 

Total (20 points)

3. Coding using GitHub with:

3(a) proof of collaboration (5 points) [ GitHub or GitLab collaboration details and Scrum meeting notes).

3(b) written description of High Cohesion and Low Coupling principles for your design (5 points)

3 (c) using JUnit (5 points)  (100% tests are green)

3 (d) using EclEmma (5 points) (100% code coverage)

Total (20 points)

4. Four types of  UML Diagrams:

Only one diagram each for examples of Use Case, Class, Activity and Sequence for portions of your code) for any part of code. It is not required to have a diagram for all aspects of your application. Please refer to Lucid Chart tutorials on YouTube. Lucid Chart is becoming popular.

4(a) Use Case Diagram (5 points)  (for part  of code  is ok)

4(b) Class Diagram (5 points) (typically is for all of your design)

4(c) Activity Diagram (5 points) (for part of code is ok)

4(d) Sequence Diagram (5 points) (for part of code is ok)

(Total 20 points)

5. Minimum 2 Design Patterns:  (If you are building your project on top of the labs then you cannot claim existing design patterns. You must include your own application of any two design patterns).

Design Pattern A: (10 points)

Design Pattern B: (10 points)

Total 20 points

Grand Total 100 points

-------------------------------------------------

BONUS POINTS:

1. Bonus Points for User Stories: ---> (5 bonus points)

(a) Validate User Story with INVEST and MOSCOW principles.

(b) Provide User Story Map.

(c) Include Definition of Done with Acceptance Criteria. 

2. Bonus Points for use of additional 2 Design Patterns in Code relevant to your problem:

--->(5 bonus points)

3. Bonus Points for using any Interaction Design Principles and any User Interface (such as HTML/JavaScript or Java Swing) --> (5 bonus points)

TOTAL BONUS POINTS: 15 points

name: Final Project Peer Evaluation
description:
1. Go to Preparation, download the worksheet your team previously submitted, and share within the team if necessary.
  2. Download Peer_Evaluation.xlsx 
  3. Rename file as  "Final Peer_Evaluation.xlsx"
  4. In the excel worksheet, fill in A2 - A11 using the criteria listed in Question 2 (in the worksheet downloaded in Step 1), and B1 - BI using all team members' names excluding yourself (sorted by alphabetical order of their last names). If you have fewer than 10 criteria or there are fewer than 8 members in your team, please leave those extra fields empty.
  5. Fill in B15 with the number of criteria in your rubrics.
  6. Evaluate your teammates performance with a scale between 1 and 10 for each criterion.
  7. Values in Row 12 and 13 should be updated automatically. If not, please debug.
  8. Submit the file through Canvas.

Note:

  • When evaluating your teammates' performance, please be fair and give an objective evaluation. The instructor reserves the right to void a peer-evaluation result if any abnormality is discovered. For example, a evaluation which blindly give all teammates the same rating on all criteria may be voided.
  • If less than half of the team members submit their evaluation, the instructor may reserve the right to not use their peer-evaluation results due to insufficient data collected.

name: Risk Management - PART I
description:
Dear students,

Please submit your Risk Management assessment to prepare you for the first phase of the Class Team Project for a sample, sample risk management scenario. I am providing here down below, the simple version I drew on board. All actions are file reads and writes as described in class.

Step1: Owner of valuable item registers item with tag ID and owner details to the server. (writes to a file).

Step 2: Owner notifies that the item is lost to the server. (writes to a file).

Step 3: The valuable item sends information about its TagID and GPS location. (since it is continuously beaming its location say at 10 minute intervals). (writes to a file)

Step 4: The Finder's cell phone picks up the TagID and GPS information (reads from a file).

Step 5:Owner receives information from server that Item is found with GPS information (Search and match is done through files and a Print statement says "Owner X with Address Y is notified that Owner's item I with Tag ID T was found at GPS location G". The X, Y, I, T and G values are filled in.

Each of the steps is done by running an application.

Please submit a table in PDF document. The table must contain Predictable and Un-Predictable risks as columns and in PEOPLE, PROCESS And PRODUCT categories as rows, and how the risks will be handled. There must be at least two categories in Predictable risks and two categories in Un-Predictable risks and a total of at least 5 risks.  Provide your strategy in a second column on how you will handle each risk.  You may include a maximum of 10 risks. Only 5 risks will be graded.

Before you submit make sure you have submitted your team name and team members list.

name: PA1 OOP Review (**Optional for Bonus points only**)
description:
Programming Assignment 1: OOP Review

THIS IS A GROUP ASSIGNMENT FOR PROJECT TEAMS.

1 Purpose

The primary purpose of this assignment is to help you review (and demonstrate that you have acquired) the knowledge and skills required to program in Java. From a language and algorithms perspective, there is nothing new in this assignment. There is also nothing new from a software engineering perspective.

This assignment will also help you gain some experience with the integrated development environment that you will be using this semester in this course. Some of the tools you will be using this semester will be new to some of you. Regardless of whether you have used them in the past, at this point, you should be able to figure out everything that you need for this assignment.

2 Overview

SagaciousMedia is a (fictitious) company that develops educational hardware, software, and content for both the formal and informal education markets. SagaciousMedia's products are designed to excite and educate students, and to inspire and assist teachers/instructors.

They are in the process of developing a suite of products for working with grading assignments of various kinds (e.g., exams, homework assignments, labs, programming assignments). They have hired you to construct several interfaces/classes that will, ultimately, become part of these products.

These classes/interfaces might be used by the first application they are creating (called Gradient) to calculate the numerical grade for a course that has 6 programming assignments (with the lowest dropped) that account for 40% of the course grade, 5 homework assignments that account for 10% of the course grade, one midterm exam that accounts for 20% of the course grade, and a final exam that accounts for 30% of the course grade. For example, assuming the programming assignments and homework assignments are each graded on a 20-point scale and the exams are each graded on a 100-point scale, the following grades

  20.0 18.0 5.0 15.0 20.0 20.0 20.0 5.0 0.0 10.0 15.0 80.0 75.0

should result in a PA grade of 20.0+18.0+ 15.0+20.0+20.0=98.0, a homework grade of 20.0+5.0+0.0+10.0+15.0=50.0 and a course grade of 0.4(93.0)+0.1(50.0)+0.2(80.0)+0.3(75.0)=37.2+5.0+16.0+22.5=80.7.

(Note that, one PA assignment is dropped)

3 Preparatory Tasks

Before you do anything else you should:
  1. Install the latest version of Eclipse on your computer. (Using other IDEs should be OK for this assignment. But since later in the semester we will practice using Eclipse for debugging, static analysis, and working with Git, it would be better to start using it now.)
  2. Read all policies related to homework assignments in the syllabus.

4 Documents

Sagacious Media uses a software process called Scrum. As a result, the documents they have created are organized in a particular way.

The terms that Sagacious Media uses when discussing Gradient and its functionality are described in the following document.

  • Product Domain Glossary

The requirements of the first product they are building, Gradient, have been organized into what are called stories. Epics are abstract stories that might take several releases (developed over the course of many months) to completely realize. Each release has its own set of sprintable stories that describe its features. Both the epics and the sprintable stories (which are what you are concerned with for this assignment) for Gradient have been collected in the following document.

  • Stories for Gradient

The existing team at Sagacious Media used the sprintable stories to create a set of tasks for this assignment. They completed some of the tasks and have left others for you to complete. The complete set of tasks is contained in the following document.

  • Tasks for Gradient

The tasks that are "checked" have already been completed by other team members, the evidence for which is contained in the following documents (which are listed in alphabetical order).

  • Engineering Design for Gradient
  • Implementation of the Gradient class
  • Specification of the DropFilter class
  • Specification of the the Grade class
  • Specification of the Missing class
  • Specification of the SizeException class
  • Specification of the TotalStrategy class
  • Specification of the WeightedTotalStrategy class
  • System/Integration Tests for Gradient

You must complete the tasks that have not been "checked-off".

5 A Recommended Process

The tasks that were identified by the team at Sagacious Media are organized by story. Hence, though they are numbered so that they can be referred to in documents and conversations, the numbers should not, in any way, influence the order in which you complete them. I would suggest you sequence your activities as follows.
  1. Read all of the documents carefully. (This is utterly important, which is often ignored, unfortunately.)
  2. Review the source code for the Gradient class so that you understand how the classes you are implementing will be used.
  3. Implement the Grade class.
  4. Test and debug the Grade class.
  5. Implement the Missing class.
  6. Test and debug the Missing class.
  7. Implement the SizeException class.
  8. Implement the GradingStrategy interface.
  9. Think about how the WeightedTotalStrategy and TotalStrategy classes should be related (if at all).
  10. Implement the WeightedTotalStrategy or TotalStrategy class (whichever one you think should be implemented first).
  11. Test and debug the class you just implemented.
  12. Implement the WeightedTotalStrategy or TotalStrategy class (whichever one you think should be implemented second).
  13. Test and debug the class you just implemented.
  14. Implement the Filter interface.
  15. Implement the DropFilter class.
  16. Test and debug the DropFilter class.
  17. Test and debug the complete system.

Note that, you will need to have a stubbed-out version of all of the classes for your code to compile. This will, hopefully, encourage you to create and use stubs (i.e., pieces of code that stand in for the code that would be needed to provide full functionality) as part of your development process.

6 Getting Help

Note that these links may not be available now. Hence google for these concepts.
  • Object and Classes
  • Packages and Namespaces
  • The Static Model

7 Submission

Please create a zip file including all your source code, and submit the zip file through Canvas. By default, your latest submission will be graded. Also submit a PDF file with proof of your test results.

8 Grading

Partial credit will be awarded. Your grade will be based on the percentage of the system tests (worth 7*10 = 70 points) that your classes pass and on the quality of your code (30 points), as determined by our grader.

Since we have not discussed unit testing yet you will not be penalized now if your classes do not conform to the specifications (as long as your system passes the system tests). However, you will be penalized for such defects in the future. Hence, you should strive to write code that conforms to the specifications (and test it as best you can). Also, you should strive to write code that is clear, elegant, and well-documented.

Rule of Thumb: Start Early, Read, Think.

description:

However you may work with others - this is a bonus points lab and so, write only those student names who you believe sincerely worked with you on top page and make sure only one student submits.  It does not matter if a student was involved but if the student was not contributing  please do not include the students name on top of the assignment for this lab. 

Please follow the instructions on the document below and pay attention to the rubric. This Lab is meant to get your feet wet in Cloud Architecture. Most organizations are hosting their applications on the cloud now. So this lab will give you confidence from getting a basic common sense knowledge of cloud architecture.  This architecture does mirror some features of client/server architecture although it has more advantages than disadvantages of traditional client server architecture. This lab carries bonus points. Provide in a PDF file all the screen shots.

name: LAB-ARCH-CONTAINER-04-Docker and CI/CD Concepts (**OPTIONAL for Bonus points only**)
description:
Dear Students,

This is an individual assignment. However you may work with others - this is a bonus points lab and so, write only those student names who you believe sincerely worked with you on top page and make sure only one student submits.  It does not matter if a student was involved but if the student was not contributing  please do not include the students name on top of the assignment for this lab. 

Please submit screen shots in a PDF File.

Give this lab your best attempt and learn Docker "Container" concepts and very simple CI/CD pipeline with GitHub. 

Docker = A container that allows you to virtualize a new operating system on your existing operating system.

C = Continuous

I = Integration

D = Deployment

CI/CD = Continuous Integration/Continuous Deployment

 

https://github.com/BalmaBrian/git-started

Submit a PDF of screen shots.

 

NOTE: Do you have Docker already installed before starting on your lab?

IF YOU DO NOT ALREADY HAVE DOCKER ON YOUR LAPTOP THEN FOLLOW THESE INSTRUCTIONS FROM SACSTATE ECS SUPPORT:

In case you do not have Docker already installed and working on your laptop, then follow these instructions.

INSTRUCTIONS FROM SACSTATE ECS SUPPORT:

 

I have completed the VMware VM for your class. The following link is a direct link to download the VM which is in a zip folder. Please note that people with existing access can use the link.
https://mysacstate.sharepoint.com/:u:/r/sites/ecs/Shared%20Documents/Docker%20VM/Ubuntu%2064-bit.zip?csf=1&web=1&e=qN4NQx

This Ubuntu VM if fully updated and has Docker, AWS CLi 2, & VScode installed. Docker has been tested while the AWS CLi is operational and just needs students to link there AWS account to the tool. VScode was installed out of convenience and we recommend using the "Remote Development using SSH" tools on VScode if your students want to use the VScode editor on the VM. Here is a link to setting up and using the "Remote Development using SSH" tool for VScode: https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/remote/ssh

The account created on the VM is called hornet. The following is important information on the user account:
- Username: hornet
- Password: gohornets
- Sudo Password: gohornets

One you download the zip folder, unzip it. After that to launch the VM in VMware, double click the file called "Ubuntu 64-bit.vmx". We fully recommend to save the unzipped VM in your U-Drive because it is faster to link a U-Drive on a sassafras system than it is to use OneDrive and redownload the VM every time a students uses a Sassafras machine. U-Drive instructions can be read here: [code]KB0010301 : How to set up SacFiles (U Drive) (Links to an external site.)[/code]

Please let us know if you need further assistance with the VM in addition to letting us know how the VM works for you,

Brian Almaguer
ECS Help Desk
helpdesk@ecs.csus.edu
ecs-helpdesk@csus.edu

 

Best,

:)

Jagan

name: Optional Programming Assignments (from the optional PA group)
Mid Term - Part-1
description:
Dear students,

This is part-1 of your midterm. Part-1 constitutes 50% of your midterm. You have a wide amount of time to submit, until April 9th, 11:59pm.

PART1: For part1 since some questions are problem solving, you may answer the problem-solving questions inline in the text box on Canvas or by writing clearly on paper (especially activity diagram) and take a camera picture or use Draw.io, Visio or Lucid Chart or any similar diagramming tool and upload the exported file as a PDF file. (Hint: If you generated a picture file, you could insert into a word document and save it as a PDF file).

I am pretty sure you can complete part-1 in an hour or leisurely in a day if you put your mind and focus on it.  Only one attempt is allowed: Which means: After you hit the final quiz submit button, Canvas understands you completed answering the mid-term and so you may not go back to change your answers.

Canvas continuously saves your work. If you exit without hitting the submit button, when you return each time, Canvas will bring up all your previous work.  Until you complete the mid-term and hit the submit button, Canvas allows you to change your answers.

This test is open book and open notes. 

 No collaboration or use of internet is allowed. Work individually on this part-1 midterm and submit individually.

Please adhere ardently to the SacState Honor principle. I trust you.

You can collaborate only on MIDTERM Part-2 on Scrum Reading Summary which can be submitted as one document per team. There is a separate assignment for part-2.

Best wishes and cheers,

:)

Jagan

name: Mid Term -- Part 2 (Scrum Reading Summary) submit PDF document
description:
Dear students,

YES, THIS IS PART OF YOUR MIDTERM, HOWEVER IT IS TEAM-WORK.

You can get started on Part 2 of Mid Term right away.  This will consist of Scrum Reading.  Module 3 has Scrum.pdf and Scrum-Guide-US.pdf. 

Please keep summarizing every day in as simple a way as possible, a couple pages or paragraphs, at your pace, in a Word document from Scrum.pdf and Scrum-Guide-US.pdf.  At the end of the task, after completing you can submit by the due date.

*****For part 2 all of you will get 90%-100% points just for completing this part sincerely. You are not required to be perfect, only complete the reading with a daily summary accumulated in a Word document.  Finally convert (export) the Word document as a PDF file and submit the file. ****

For Part-2 you may discuss collaboratively.  Then do your best to write in your own simple words. Keep it very simple.  Part-2 will help you immensely for interview preparations. Work individually and collaboratively and submit as a Team. 

ONLY ONE STUDENT FROM TEAM WILL SUBMIT THE SUMMARY.

Best wishes,

Jagan

name: Self Assessment Survey & Portfolio Submission
description:
The following survey was developed using the Canvas Quiz tool.

It is not a quiz (even if Canvas has a label that says "quiz" in some places on the screen). There are no wrong answers on this survey.

You are required to complete this survey in order to receive a WPJ Score

Am I Ready to Start This Survey?

If you have selected two assignments that will be your writing samples for the WPJ Portfolio, then you are ready to start the survey.

If you have not already selected two assignments, please review the instructions for selecting assignments before proceeding.

If you are ready, you can start this exercise.

There are two parts to the portfolio that you are required to complete:

  1. The self-assessment survey (Questions 1 - 34)
  2. The upload slots for assignments you've selected as writing samples for your portfolio (Questions 35 - 36)

The Self-Assessment Survey

The survey is a mix of multiple-choice, fill-in-the-blank, and short-response questions.

It takes most students between 30-45 minutes to complete. Some students, however, take more time because they want to explain the choices they made when picking writing samples. It is acceptable (even encouraged) to use the survey to share any information you think will help the readers. 

The survey asks the following types of questions:

  • Questions about you (6 questions)
  • Questions about the first assignment for your portfolio (13 questions)
  • Questions about the second assignment for your portfolio (13 questions)
  • Question about the whole portfolio (2 questions)

The WPJ Readers who score your portfolio will pay attention to the answers you provide in the self-assessment survey because it helps them better understand how you have developed as a writer, why you selected the assignments you've included as writing samples, and how you work through the process of writing for college courses. 

The Assignment Upload Slots

At the end of the survey, you will find two slots where you will upload the two assignments you are submitting as writing samples. 

These assignments must meet the required criteria for the WPJ Portfolio.  

After you complete the survey and upload your assignments, click "submit" and you are done.

NOTES

  • Do not click submit until you are done with the entire survey.
  • The survey has an autosave feature that functions whenever you have a reliable internet connection. So you can complete this survey in stages if you would like.  
  • Your survey responses will not be graded/scored based on their grammar or mechanics, but readers do need to be able to understand your answers.

rubric_settings.title: Writing Program Outcomes Rubric for WPJ Portfolios

ratings.description: Exemplary - Demonstrates sophisticated ability to summarize, analyze, and synthesize a credible and relevant body of literature.
Accomplished - Demonstrates ability to summarize, analyze, and synthesize a credible and relevant body of literature.
Developing - Demonstrates ability to summarize and analyze a relevant body of literature.
Beginner - Demonstrates ability to summarize a relevant body of literature.

rubric.long_description: The ability to summarize, analyze, and synthesize a credible and relevant body of literature.

ratings.description: Exemplary - Establishes a carefully articulated idea with a strong sense of purpose and appropriateness for audience.
Accomplished - Establishes a meaningful controlling idea with a clear sense of purpose and appropriateness for audience.
Developing - Establishes a controlling idea with a sense of purpose and appropriateness for audience.
Beginner - Establishes an idea with a sense of purpose.

rubric.long_description: The ability to articulate an idea with a strong sense of purpose and appropriateness for the audience.

ratings.description: Exemplary - Utilizes task-appropriate organization to create a sophisticated argument that makes effective connections between claims supported by discipline-appropriate evidence.
Accomplished - Utilizes task-appropriate organization to create a consistent argument that makes effective connections between claims supported by discipline-appropriate evidence.
Developing - Utilizes task-appropriate organization to create an argument that makes connections between claims supported by evidence.
Beginner - Utilizes an organizational structure to create an argument that makes connections between claims supported by evidence.

rubric.long_description: The ability to organize a text to create an argument that makes connections between claims supported by discipline-appropriate evidence.

ratings.description: Exemplary - Demonstrates scholarly use of language that skillfully communicates meaning with few grammatical errors, making misinterpretation unlikely. All in-text citations are appropriately written for a given discipline.

Accomplished - Demonstrates effective use of language that clearly communicates meaning with few grammatical errors, making misinterpretation unlikely. Most of the in-text citations are appropriately written for the given discipline.

Developing - Demonstrates control of language that communicates meaning with clarity. Grammatical errors rarely interfere with communication. The majority of in-text citations are appropriately written for the given discipline.
Beginner - While grammatical errors may interfere with communication, the text demonstrates control of language that communicates meaning. In-text citations are utilized.

rubric.long_description: The ability to communicate meaning with few grammatical errors, making misinterpretation unlikely.

ratings.description: Exemplary - Demonstrates mastery of the ways in which one proceeds through the various writing processes associated with the task.
Accomplished - Demonstrates thorough understanding of the ways in which one proceeds through the various writing processes associated with the task.
Developing - Demonstrates understanding of the ways in which one proceeds through the various writing processes associated with the task.
Beginner - Demonstrates an awareness of ways in which one proceeds through the various writing processes associated with the task.

rubric.long_description: The ability to proceed through the various writing processes associated with the task.

name: Portfolio Scores and Advising Notes - Due Date is the date scores are released
description:
What is this Assignment?

This is not an assignment. There is nothing for you to submit. This is where you will receive the score for your portfolio and an advising note intended to help you as you move into the final stage of the Graduation Writing Assessment Requirement: The Writing Intensive course.

The Scoring of Your Portfolio

A member of the GWAR Portfolio Reading Team is going to take a look at your self-assessment and your portfolio. Based on what we find there, we will give your portfolio a score of 0-5. 

Here is a brief explanation of what each score:

0 - Incomplete Portfolio

The portfolio is incomplete and therefore does not meet the basic requirements for moving on to take a Writing Intensive course. If you receive a Zero, you will have to wait until the next submission date. 

1 - Developing Writer 

The development of your writing ability is still at an early stage for a college-level writer. Upper-division writing assignments will likely present serious challenges. The most effective way to meet these challenges is by seeking out more writing instruction.

2 - Developing Understanding of Grammar & Mechanics 

The development of your writing ability is still at an early stage for a college-level writer, but the major challenges you will face in upper-division writing are related to issues of grammar and mechanics. These types of challenges are best addressed through courses on grammar and/or extra time and assistance while proofreading and editing of your work.

3 - Competent Writer 

Your writing demonstrates many of the traits of a college-level writer. Upper-division writing assignments will be challenging, but you have the tools required to meet those challenges. You may, however, require some assistance while learning to use those tools in new or unfamiliar writing situations. 

4 - Strong Writer

Your writing demonstrates the traits of a college-level writer. Upper-division writing assignments will be challenging, but you have the skills required to meet those challenges. You still may be interested in seeking assistance while working in new or unfamiliar writing situations. 

5 - Exceptional Writer

Your self-assessment and the material in your portfolio demonstrate a strong understanding of writing and the process of composing cogent and engaging texts. It may not be easy moving those skills into new or unfamiliar writing situations, but you have a strong set of skills to support those kinds of transitions. 

Advising Note

Scores will be accompanied by an Advising Note.

The advising note will provide some guidance for you as you move on to the final stage of the GWAR - passing a Writing Intensive course.

The Writing Intensive (WI) courses at Sacramento State are a very important part of your development as a writer. They are not writing courses because" learning to write" is not the primary goal of WI courses. They are courses with upper-division content that you will need to learn and then write about. One of the main ways you will be assessed (graded) in these courses is through the writing you do. You will not, however, get the same level of writing support that you get in writing courses like English 10/11, English 5, or English 20. 

For this reason, each score will be accompanied by a note that describes on-campus writing resources for students working to complete the GWAR.
